data.title: Dow, S&P, and Nasdaq rise despite China hitting back with tariffs on U.S. imports
data.description:
Wall Street trades higher on Tuesday despite the fact that China retaliated with a levy of tariffs on imports of multiple U.S. products.

Early on and the S&P 500 (SP500) was +0.4%, the Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) was +1.1%, and the Dow (DJI) was near flat.

The 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) rose 1 basis point to 4.58%. The 2-year yield (US2Y) fell 1 basis point to 4.24%.

The tech focused Nasdaq has been helped by shares of Palantir Technologies (PLTR) which popped over 25% after the firm's fourth quarter 2024 results and outlook blasted past expectations.

On the tariff front, the Chinese government said it would implement a 15% tariff on coal and liquefied natural gas products, as well as a 10% tariff on crude oil, agricultural machinery, and large-displacement cars.

Wall Street closed lower on Monday after President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on Canada and Mexico over the weekend. While it was a red day, markets were able to recoup some earlier losses after delays were announced against tariffs towards Mexico.

"The past 24 hours have seen a big roundtrip for many assets classes as strongly negative sentiment gave way to a relief rally on news that the planned 25% tariffs against Mexico and Canada would be delayed," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said.

"Taxing goods from China is still happening, and China has retaliated. The inflation consequences of these taxes are less obvious to US consumers," UBS' Paul Donovan said.

On the earnings side, Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) (GOOG) is expected to release its fourth quarter results today.

U.S. factory orders fell 0.9% M/M to $578.5B in December. Additionally, job openings drop more than expected in December while hiring rate stagnates.

data.title: Glucotrack soars on completion of first human clinical study of continuous blood glucose monitor
data.description:
Glucotrack (NASDAQ:GCTK) on Tuesday reported the successful completion of its first in human clinical study, sending shares up ~60% in the morning trade.

This study represents first real-time, continuous blood glucose monitor (CBGM) placed in the subclavian vein, offering the potential for direct blood glucose measurement without the limitations often seen with traditional continuous glucose monitors, the company said.

“While neither the study nor prototype system was designed to evaluate sensor accuracy, the system performed as expected with similar accuracy results as previously seen in our animal studies,” said Glucotrack (NASDAQ:GCTK) CEO Paul V. Goode.

“With these positive results, the promise of continuous blood glucose monitoring is one step closer to reality.”

The study met its primary endpoint, with no procedure or device related serious adverse events reported from implant through seven days post-removal of the CBGM sensor lead.

Glucotrack (NASDAQ:GCTK) is down 84% year-to-date.

data.title: Regeneron's new dividend, Dupixent growth support strong Q4
data.description:
• While Regeneron's (NASDAQ:REGN) Q4 financial results were a top and bottom line beat, perhaps the biggest development from the release was the announcement of the company's first dividend payment.
  • It will be a quarterly dividend of $0.88/share for a 0.53% forward yield. It is payable March 20 for shareholders of record as of Feb. 20.
  • In the quarter, Regeneron (NASDAQ:REGN) saw its non-GAAP net income increase 2% to ~$1.4B ($12.07 per share, diluted).
  • Global sales of Dupixent (dupilumab), which is co-marketed with Sanofi (SNY) rose 15% to $3.7B compared to Q4 2023.
  • Worldwide sales for the Eylea (aflibercept) franchise rose 2% year over year to $1.5B.
  • In the quarter, Regeneron also repurchased $976M worth of stock.

data.title: Premier raises EPS guidance amid supply chain services growth and new member wins
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Premier, Inc. (NASDAQ:PINC) Q2 2025

Management View

  • President and CEO Michael J. Alkire stated that overall revenue and profitability for the first half of fiscal 2025 aligned with expectations, driven by better-than-expected results in the supply chain services segment. The company reaffirmed total net revenue guidance and raised its adjusted EPS guidance despite challenges in the performance services segment.
  • The company announced the successful transition of its digital supply chain strategy beyond the pilot phase, signing its first agreement with a major partner. This reflects the growing demand for Premier's provider-focused data and market intelligence.
  • David Zito was introduced as the new President of Performance Services, bringing extensive healthcare consulting expertise to drive innovation and growth in the segment.
  • CFO Glenn Coleman highlighted that second-quarter revenue and adjusted EBITDA were below expectations, but adjusted EPS of $0.25 met expectations due to share repurchases. He noted that net revenue of $240 million reflected a decline, primarily driven by lower net administrative fees in Supply Chain Services and decreased consulting revenue in Performance Services.

Outlook

  • Premier raised its adjusted EPS guidance midpoint by $0.08, reflecting the positive impact of the $200 million share repurchase completed in January.
  • Supply Chain Services revenue guidance midpoint was increased by $25 million due to favorable fee share trends and new member wins, including AllSpire Health Partners.
  • The company anticipates flat to slightly higher net administrative fees in the third quarter, followed by a sequential increase in the fourth quarter as new member spending ramps up. Performance Services revenue is expected to remain back-end weighted, with stronger contributions in the fourth quarter.
  • Adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS for the second half of fiscal 2025 are projected to be slightly more weighted toward the fourth quarter.

Financial Results

  • Revenue for Q2 2025 was reported at $240 million, below analysts’ revenue estimate of $243.2 million. Adjusted EPS of $0.25 also missed analysts’ estimate of $0.30.
  • GAAP net loss from continuing operations was $46 million, primarily driven by a $127 million goodwill impairment charge related to the Performance Services segment.
  • Adjusted EBITDA was $50 million, with a margin of 20.8%, impacted by lower revenue.
  • Free cash flow for the first half of fiscal 2025 totaled $74 million, up $33 million year-over-year, supported by a derivative lawsuit settlement and minority investment distributions.
  • As of December 31, 2024, cash and cash equivalents stood at $86 million, with $100 million outstanding on the company’s $1 billion credit facility.

Q&A

  • Michael Cherny, Leerink Partners: Questioned the company's strategies to address potential tariff impacts and ensure supply chain resiliency. CEO Alkire responded that contracts include protections against taxes and tariffs, and efforts are ongoing to diversify suppliers and reduce reliance on Southeast Asia.
  • Eric Percher, Nephron Research: Sought clarification on the drivers behind the improved net administrative fees performance. CFO Coleman stated that growth in gross administrative fees, favorable fee share impacts, and new member wins contributed positively.
  • Kevin Caliendo, UBS: Asked about the confidence behind the anticipated fourth-quarter strength in Performance Services. CFO Coleman attributed this to a strong funnel in Applied Sciences, timing of enterprise license agreements, and leadership efforts to build collaborative capabilities.
  • Richard Close, Canaccord Genuity: Inquired about consulting services challenges. CEO Alkire emphasized efforts to refresh advisory capabilities with technology-driven solutions and co-management opportunities to meet market demands.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed concerns over tariff impacts, Performance Services weakness, and the goodwill impairment charge. Their tone was slightly negative but constructive, indicating interest in understanding mitigation strategies.
  • Management displayed confidence during prepared remarks, particularly in Supply Chain Services and strategic initiatives like digital supply chain advancements. However, there was a slightly defensive tone during Q&A, with responses emphasizing ongoing efforts to address challenges.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts appeared more focused on risks, while management maintained a consistent tone of optimism about long-term strategies.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Adjusted EPS guidance was raised this quarter, unlike Q1 2025, when guidance was reaffirmed. Revenue performance in Q2 2025 fell below expectations, contrasting with Q1's stronger-than-expected results.
  • Strategic focus shifted to digital supply chain advancements and leadership changes in Performance Services, while Q1 emphasized contract renewals and hurricane-related supply chain mitigation.
  • Analysts showed increased interest in tariff impacts and net administrative fees dynamics this quarter, compared to broader utilization and contract penetration discussions in Q1.
  • Management's confidence in long-term strategies remained consistent, with enhanced focus on addressing short-term headwinds in Performance Services.

Risks and Concerns

  • A $127 million goodwill impairment charge in the Performance Services segment highlighted challenges in the data and technology business.
  • Analysts raised concerns about potential tariff impacts on supply chains and Premier’s ability to mitigate associated risks.
  • Declining consulting revenue and a shift from license agreements to SaaS subscription engagements in Applied Sciences posed short-term headwinds.
  • Potential impacts of member departures and the ongoing contract renewal process added operational uncertainty.

Final Takeaway

Premier, Inc. demonstrated resilience in its supply chain services segment, driven by favorable administrative fee trends and new member wins. However, challenges in the Performance Services segment, including a significant goodwill impairment charge, tempered overall results. Management's efforts to advance digital supply chain strategies and strengthen Performance Services under new leadership provide a pathway for future growth, but near-term headwinds warrant close monitoring by investors.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: SA Sentiment: Trump tariffs are paused, but still lack support
data.description:
Tariffs have been in the spotlight since Donald Trump took office, and any development has prompted swift reaction in equity markets.

Trump over the weekend announced 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada, starting a trade war as both countries vowed to retaliate with their own duties. This led to a market selloff on Monday as traders fled to safe-haven assets like gold.

But the White House later agreed to delay the tariffs for a month after the two countries committed to reinforce border security, leading to markets paring some losses.

Trump also announced 10% tariffs on China, which will go into effect on Tuesday, for now. Trump plans to speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping some time this week, so markets are expecting some updates here.

It appears as though Wall Street's initial expectations of Trump using tariffs as a bargaining chip may have been right after all. But the tariffs are quite unpopular with Seeking Alpha readers.

According to Monday's Sentiment Survey, more than three-quarters of the nearly 5,000 respondents do not support the new tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China.

Investing Group Leader Lawrence Fuller warned that tariff threats damage investor, consumer, and business sentiment, and increase uncertainty. "I believe Trump will ultimately retract the tariffs due to their widely advertised negative economic impacts, including reduced GDP and S&P 500 earnings."

On the other hand, James Foord believes tariffs are just what the market needs. "Tariffs can reduce economic activity and act as a sales tax, which could help ease inflation and set the stage for renewed quantitative easing."

As for Trump using tariffs as a negotiating tactic, SA analyst Cullen Roche said it could potentially get countries to do his bidding. "But how much pain is Trump willing to endure to play this game of chicken?"

data.title: Small Caps could have an opportunity in a trade war scenario – Barclays
data.description:
The one-month delay of tariffs against Mexico and Canada turnaround highlights the exceptional uncertainty surrounding a trade war that has price reaction and interest rate implications, according to Stefano Pascale, head of equity derivatives strategy at Barclays.

Barclays economists believe that the implementation of 25% tariffs would boost U.S. CPI and PCE inflation by 10-15 basis points on a percentage year-over-year basis and hit GDP by about 25-50 basis points. The Federal Reserve would then face an inflationary economy and could be forced to cut interest rates more aggressively.

“Insofar as the recent events represent one salvo in a trade war, and to the extent that it matters greatly for the Fed reaction, this debate will remain crucial for equity markets,” said Pascale.

Markets expectations around Federal Reserve cuts did not change much in the past few days, but if the Fed is forced to aggressively reduce rates in response to lower growth, “small caps could actually outperform on an equity sell-off.”

If this were to happen, analysts said, they recommend investors to buy S&P 500 (SPX) puts “partly funded by selling Russell 2000 (RTY) puts.”

“To hedge such a potential scenario, we would consider buying S&P 500 (SPX) June 25 6150 puts (ref. 5994.57, 51-delta) and selling 0.7x Russell 2000 (RTY) June 25 2300 puts (ref. 2258.42, 49-delta) for zero at inception.”

“At current costs, the historical return would have been favorable, especially in the wings (average gains greater than 90th percentile of 8.7% is 1.5x larger than the average loss greater than 95th percentile of -6.0%).”

To conclude, Pascale said that a trade war would be more damaging to internationally exposed companies. Lower interest rates would also be more beneficial to small caps (IWM), (RTY).

Lastly, CTAs (commodity trading advisors) positioning on the Russell 2000 (RTY) is currently the most short, while S&P 500 (SP500), (SPX) exposure is higher.

“The RTY vs. S&P volatility spread has compressed materially over the past month, but remains historically high; notably, the onset of the trade war during Trump 1.0 marked a regime shift lower in the spread from levels comparable to present,” he said.

data.title: Juniper upgraded ahead of earnings as potential acquisition by HPE heads to court
data.description:
Juniper Networks (NYSE:JNPR) was upgraded to Outperform from In Line by Evercore ISI ahead of its Q4 2024 earnings report and a looming case by the U.S. Department of Justice regarding a planned $14B acquisition by Hewlett Packard Enterprise (NYSE:HPE).

Evercore believes there is upside to Juniper shareholders regardless of the outcome in the upcoming trial.

"HPE is successful in their bid for JNPR, and JNPR shareholders will end-up with $40/share (15% upside)," said Evercore analysts, led by Amit Daryanani, in a Tuesday investor note. "HPE loses the DOJ trial, JNPR is an independent company, and in that scenario we think there are a host of fundamental levers that would make JNPR a good stock in 2025 – networking recovery, MIST share gains, cloud ramps (xAI and more) + margin expansion."

Regardng the lawsuit, HPE has already received approval for the acquisition by the E.U., United Kingdom, India, South Korea and Australia. However, the U.S. DOJ argues that a merger between HPE and Juniper would minimize competition in the enterprise wireless market.

Juniper is slated to report its fourth quarter results after the bell today. The consensus estimate for adjusted earnings per share is $0.57 on revenue of $1.39B.

data.title: Ball’s shares decline on weaker revenue, quarterly loss
data.description:
Ball’s (NYSE:BALL) stock on Tuesday fell as much as 8.4% after the maker of aluminum cans reported weaker revenue and a quarterly loss.

The packaging company swung to a net loss of $32 million, or $0.11 a share, in the fourth quarter from a profit of $154 million, or $0.49 a share, a year earlier.

Adjusted earnings were $0.84 a share, compared with the average estimate of $0.81 a share among Wall Street analysts.

Sales for the three-month period through December slipped to $2.88 billion from $2.9 billion. Ball (NYSE:BALL) pointed out that sales don’t include the aerospace business it sold a year ago.

Regional results

The company’s packaging business in North and Central America saw sales fall 6.5% to $1.29 billion in the quarter from $1.38 billion a year earlier. Management blamed lower volume and lower price and mix for part of the decline, which was offset somewhat by a contractual pass-through of lower aluminum costs.

In the Europe Middle East Africa region, sales in the beverage packaging segment rose 12% to $826 million from $739 million. In South America, sales fell 8.6% to $563 million from $616 million.

Forward guidance

As for the current year ahead, management estimated comparable earnings per share growth of 10%.

Comparable earnings were $3.17 a share in 2024. Analysts on average forecast earnings of $3.52 a share for 2025.

data.title: Factory orders fall more than expected in December
data.description: U.S. factory orders fell 0.9% M/M to $578.5B in December, the -0.7% consensus and -0.8% in the previous month (revised from -0.4%), according to U.S. Census Bureau data released on Tuesday.

data.title: Broadridge Financial Solutions declares $0.88 dividend
data.description:
• Broadridge Financial Solutions (NYSE:BR) declares $0.88/share quarterly dividend, in line with previous.
